Course Description: With the digital social data growing at an accelerated pace on an everyday basis, there is an urgent need for social researchers to decrypt, examine and interpret this unusually large-scale complex data fill. Doing this systemically will not only help in deciphering and understanding the social world we live in but will also help strategically combat the complex challenges of the contemporary social world. With a growing demand for such skills both in the academic and the commercial sectors, this course anchored in sociology and anthropology will provide the learners an objective view of social data issues viz. reliability, replicability, reproducibility, validity and generalizability of the data and the associated methods.

Course Outcomes.CO1: The students will be able to distinguish method and design, and apply research techniques specific to digital data collection and analysis.
Course Outcomes.CO2: The students will be able to assess the significance of digital data for social research vis-à-vis conventional social research.
Course Outcomes.CO3: The students will learn about the ethical issues related to digital social research and how to address them.
Course Outcomes.CO4: The course will enable the students to develop research proposals that make appropriate use of the learnt methods.

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Introduction: Social Research and Digital Data
Why Digital Social Research: Moving from Cyber to Digital?
Theoretical Overview of Digital Social Research
Methodological Devices: Making Digital Social | Digital Social
Ethical Implications of Digital Social Research
Student Presentations and Digital Journal Review
